'''The Minnesota Population Center ''' (MPC) is a university-wide interdisciplinary research center at the [[University of Minnesota]]. MPC was established in 2000, absorbing two earlier population research organizations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pop.umn.edu/about/history-philosophy |title=History and Philosophy of the Minnesota Population Center |publisher=University of Minnesota, Minnesota Population Center |date= |accessdate=2011-10-21}}</ref> The primary goals of the center are to foster large-scale cross-disciplinary research collaborations and to provide shared infrastructure for demographic research.<ref> {{cite web|url=http://www.pop.umn.edu/about/history-philosophy |title=By-Laws and Mission of the Minnesota Population Center |publisher=University of Minnesota, Minnesota Population Center |date= |accessdate=2011-10-21}}</ref> The center now has 100 faculty affiliates<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pop.umn.edu/people/mpc-members |title=Members of the Minnesota Population Center |publisher=University of Minnesota, Minnesota Population Center |date= |accessdate=2011-10-21}}</ref> from 10 University of Minnesota Colleges,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pop.umn.edu/about |title=About MPC |publisher=University of Minnesota, Minnesota Population Center |date= |accessdate=2011-10-21}}</ref> over 50 graduate student affiliates<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pop.umn.edu/people/gradstudent-members |title=Graduate Student Members of the Minnesota Population Center |publisher=University of Minnesota, Minnesota Population Center |date= |accessdate=2011-10-21}}</ref> and 120 administrative and research staff.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pop.umn.edu/people/staff |title=MPC Staff |publisher=University of Minnesota, Minnesota Population Center |date= |accessdate=2011-10-21}}</ref>
The primary activity of MPC is demographic research; work at the center is divided into eight major themes:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pop.umn.edu/research/research_themes |title=Research Themes of the Minnesota Population Center |publisher=University of Minnesota, Minnesota Population Center |date= |accessdate=2011-10-21}}</ref> * Large-scale demographic data infrastructure * Work, family, and time-use * Historical demography * Education, labor, and the life-course * Healthcare access and health disparities * Census and survey methodology * Unions and sexuality * Population and environment
MPC is the producer and distributor of the world's largest demographic data collections.<ref name="interdisciplinary61">Matthew Sobek; Lara Cleveland; Sarah Flood; Patricia Kelly Hall; Miriam L. King; [[Steven Ruggles]]; Matthew Schroeder, "Big Data: Large-Scale Historical Infrastructure from the Minnesota Population Center." Historical Methods: A Journal of Quantitative and Interdisciplinary History 44:2 (2011), pages 61-68.</ref> These data collections include the [[IPUMS|Integrated Public Use Microdata Series]] (IPUMS),<ref>[[Steven Ruggles]]; Matthew Sobek; Miriam L. King; Carolyn Liebler; Catherine A. Fitch, "IPUMS Redesign," Historical Methods: A Journal of Quantitative and Interdisciplinary History 36:1 (2003), pages 9-19.</ref> the [[National Historical Geographic Information System]] (NHGIS),<ref>Catherine Fitch and [[Steven Ruggles]], "Building the National Historical Geographic Information System," Historical Methods: A Journal of Quantitative and Interdisciplinary History 36:1 (2003), pages 41-51.</ref> the [[North Atlantic Population Project]] (NAPP),<ref>[[Steven Ruggles]]; Evan Roberts; Sula Sarkar; Matthew Sobek, "The North Atlantic Population Project: Progress and Prospects," Historical Methods: A Journal of Quantitative and Interdisciplinary History 44:1 (2011), pages 1-6.</ref> and the Integrated Health Interview Series (IHIS).<ref>Pamela J. Johnson, Lynn A. Blewett, [[Steven Ruggles]], Michael E. Davern, and Miriam L. King, “Four Decades of Population Health Data: The Integrated Health Interview Series.” Epidemiology, 19:6 (2008), pages 872-875.</ref> Over 40,000 demographic researchers worldwide are registered to use these data collections.<ref name="interdisciplinary61"/>
